thread.title: Using programmable bracelets to get girls excited about coding
thread.title_full: Using programmable bracelets to get girls excited about coding

author: Caroline Lewis
title: Using programmable bracelets to get girls excited about coding
text:
Photo: Buck Ennis Sara Chipps founded Girl Develop It five years ago before moving into wearable technology 
Five years after founding Girl Develop It, a nonprofit that teaches women how to code, Sara Chipps has set her sights a little smaller. Her new company, Jewelbots, sells programmable friendship bracelets for girls ages 9 to 14. 
Out of the box, each Bluetooth-powered Jewelbot allows its wearer to use a smartphone app to set the bracelet’s flower-shaped charm to buzz when friends are nearby or light up when she gets a new Instagram follower. More-advanced kids can use open-source software to program their bracelets. 
“One thing I kept hearing from Girl Develop It students was that they wished they had even thought of engineering as a field they could get into when they were younger,” said Ms. Chipps, who is 34 but was 12 when she began learning to code. She went on to study computer science at Penn State University. 
Ms. Chipps said her bracelets remind her of the reason she got into computers: because she wanted to make friends. As a child, she connected with people via bulletin-board services—pre-Internet servers that featured message boards and games. 
Today, Jewelbots capitalizes on a growing movement to introduce girls to the science, technology, engineering and mathematics fields early on. 
“We’ve hosted two hackathons so far, and these 8- and 9-year-old girls really get into it,” said Ms. Chipps. “They’re not intimidated.” 
When the Lower East Side-based company launched its Kickstarter campaign in July, it sold 1,600 units in 10 days. Single bracelets cost $59, and a pair go for $89. The campaign generated $166,945, far surpassing its $30,000 goal. An additional $440,000 was garnered through investors. 
Ms. Chipps expects manufacturing to begin this year. The first bracelets will be shipped by spring. A version of this article appears in the October 5, 2015, print issue of Crain's New York Business.
